G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: This is a civil action for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14.

G.L. c. 186.proposition: At all times relevant hereto, Defendant has acted as Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of G.L. c. 186 and G.L. c. 239, and has been responsible for compliance with the statutory and common-law obligations owed by landlords to residential tenants in Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 239.proposition: At all times relevant hereto, Defendant has acted as Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of G.L. c. 186 and G.L. c. 239, and has been responsible for compliance with the statutory and common-law obligations owed by landlords to residential tenants in Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 223.proposition: Venue is therefore proper in the Somerville District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223 and G.L. c. 218, § 19.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: Venue is therefore proper in the Somerville District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223 and G.L. c. 218, § 19.

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A.proposition: In addition to G.L. c. 186, § 14, Plaintiff’s claim and the relief sought are consistent with related landlord–tenant protections and concepts recognized in Massachusetts law, including but not limited to G.L. c. 239, § 8A (defenses and counterclaims in summary process), G.L. c. 93A (unfair or deceptive practices, where applicable), and the implied warranty of habitability recognized in Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973); however, in this action Plaintiff asserts only the statutory and common-law claim for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.

G.L. c. 93A.proposition: In addition to G.L. c. 186, § 14, Plaintiff’s claim and the relief sought are consistent with related landlord–tenant protections and concepts recognized in Massachusetts law, including but not limited to G.L. c. 239, § 8A (defenses and counterclaims in summary process), G.L. c. 93A (unfair or deceptive practices, where applicable), and the implied warranty of habitability recognized in Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973); however, in this action Plaintiff asserts only the statutory and common-law claim for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied by law into residential tenancies in Massachusetts and is also expressed in Plaintiff’s lease.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.support_reasoning: The opinion acknowledges that Wideman brought a counterclaim for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and notes that the judge found a breach, but it does not discuss or hold that the covenant is implied by law into residential tenancies, nor does it state that it was also an express term of this particular lease. The case focuses on damages for breach of the implied warranty of habitability and related issues, not on the source (implied vs. express) of the quiet enjoyment covenant. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition stated.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.relevant_excerpt: “Wideman filed counterclaims alleging (1) breach of the implied warranty of habitability; (2) breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, see G. L. c. 186, § 14 (1992 ed.); … Although the judge found a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, he awarded no damages on this claim to avoid what would have been a duplicative award. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 107-111 (1982).”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied by law into residential tenancies in Massachusetts and is also expressed in Plaintiff’s lease.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly recognizes an implied covenant (warranty) of quiet enjoyment in favor of residential tenants in Massachusetts and treats its breach as a defense to a rent action. However, in the excerpt provided the court does not state that the covenant is also expressly set out in the plaintiffs’ lease; the discussion proceeds entirely in terms of an implied covenant and constructive eviction. Thus the case supports the implied-by-law component of the proposition but not the further assertion that the covenant was also expressed in the lease.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances coming from nearby premises which the landlords leased to others for use as a bar or cocktail lounge (lounge). ... Our opinions concerning a constructive eviction by an alleged breach of an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment sometimes have stated that the landlord must perform some act with the intent of depriving the tenant of the enjoyment and occupation of the whole or part of the leased premises.

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.proposition: A landlord may be held liable for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment where the landlord, by action or inaction, directly or indirectly allows conditions that substantially interfere with the tenant’s beneficial use of the premises to persist.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.support_reasoning: The court recounts its prior interpretations of G.L. c. 186, § 14 and explicitly states that landlords may be liable where they negligently fail to repair or correct known defects, and that such failures, whose natural and probable consequence is interference with the tenant’s use and enjoyment, constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The discussion emphasizes both omissions (inaction) and conduct that ‘directly or indirectly’ interferes with quiet enjoyment, matching the proposition that liability arises when a landlord allows substantially interfering conditions to persist. The holding narrows liability to at least negligent conduct but clearly affirms that negligent action or inaction that allows such conditions can breach the covenant.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.relevant_excerpt: “In 1973, the statute was rewritten and the requirement of intentional conduct was eliminated; landlords could now be held liable for ‘directly or indirectly’ interfering with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises… we rejected a claim that a violation of G. L. c. 186, § 14, could be imposed only if it were proved that a landlord was reckless… and we concluded that negligent conduct, conduct involving ‘some degree of fault,’ by a landlord could support the imposition of liability under § 14. We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’”}

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284–85 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Likewise, Massachusetts courts have recognized that persistent disturbances and conditions caused by other tenants or third parties may support a claim for breach of quiet enjoyment when the landlord, with notice, fails to take reasonable steps within his control to abate the condition.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The court squarely holds that pervasive disturbances and dangerous conditions caused by third parties in common areas can amount to a breach of quiet enjoyment where the landlord, with notice, fails to take reasonable steps within its control to abate them. The opinion explains that if the housing authority "stood idle" despite tenant complaints and available measures to remove nontenants engaged in unlawful activity, that inaction can constitute a serious interference with tenants’ quiet enjoyment and a breach of G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “We do believe, however, that if the defendant has failed to take any measures, especially those measures which can be undertaken relatively easily, to remove unwelcome persons from the property that it owns and controls, and the presence of those persons seriously interferes with the tenancy, then the defendant may be liable for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: Massachusetts law does not require that the landlord personally make noise or physically enter the premises; substantial interference resulting from the landlord’s failure to control foreseeable and controllable third-party conduct is sufficient.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses whether a landlord can be liable for interference with quiet enjoyment and related statutory duties when the immediate cause of the problem is third-party conduct (other tenants misusing plumbing). The court explicitly rejects the landlord’s argument that it should not be held responsible for actions of third parties beyond its control, emphasizing that the flooding was a preventable situation the landlord had a duty to prevent. The holding thus supports the proposition that Massachusetts law does not require the landlord personally to create the noise/condition or physically enter, so long as there is substantial interference resulting from the landlord’s failure to control foreseeable and controllable third‑party conduct.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “As its third objection to Solomon’s recovery on her count for interference with quiet enjoyment, Gem asserts that it was wrongly held responsible for the actions of third parties beyond its control. Pointing to its plumber’s testimony that waste backups were caused by tenants’ using unauthorized washing machines or introducing objects into the waste stacks … Gem argues that it was unable to control the source of the flooding. … We reject it for the same reasons. The water in Solomon’s apartment was a preventable situation, and one that Gem had a duty to prevent.”

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: In addition to G.L. c. 186, § 14, Plaintiff’s claim and the relief sought are consistent with related landlord–tenant protections and concepts recognized in Massachusetts law, including but not limited to G.L. c. 239, § 8A (defenses and counterclaims in summary process), G.L. c. 93A (unfair or deceptive practices, where applicable), and the implied warranty of habitability recognized in Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973); however, in this action Plaintiff asserts only the statutory and common-law claim for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: The proposition cites Hemingway specifically for the existence of an implied warranty of habitability as a related landlord–tenant protection, while clarifying that the plaintiff in the present action is proceeding only on quiet enjoyment. In this concurring/dissenting opinion, Justice Quirico expressly agrees that the court is abandoning the older caveat-emptor rule and recognizing a new implied obligation tied to minimum standards of habitability, even though he disputes how broadly the majority defines that warranty. Thus, Hemingway is indeed proper authority for the recognition in Massachusetts law of an implied warranty of habitability as a related landlord–tenant concept.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: I agree with the majority of the court that, at least as to dwelling units, the time has come to reconsider the rule so long imbedded in our law of landlord and tenant that "[t]here is no implied agreement, apart from fraud, that the demised premises are or will continue to be fit for occupancy or safe and in good repair..." ... As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards....
